content: The Act may be cited as the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008". The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define hydrographic data as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 defines hydrographic services as the management, interpretation, and dissemination of various types of marine information, including nautical charts and databases, nautical information systems, and related activities. The Coast and Geodetic Survey Act of 1947 defines the functions and duties of the Coast and Geodetic Survey. The Coast and Geodetic Survey Act of 1947 defines the functions and duties of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, including the functions of the Administrator. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 amends Section 303 by updating the duties of the Administration to promote safe marine transportation and provide hydrographic services. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 amends Section 303 to promote safe marine transportation by procuring vessels, equipment, and technologies for safe navigation, operating real-time hydrographic monitoring systems, and enhancing navigation safety and efficiency. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 allows for the acquisition of hydrographic data to support conservation, management of resources, and emergency response efforts, including saving lives, protecting property, and ensuring maritime security. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 allows for the acquisition of hydrographic data to support conservation, resource management, and emergency response efforts. HYDROGRAPHIC SERVICES REVIEW PANEL. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to specify the composition of the panel, consisting of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator. The Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees serve as nonvoting members. Voting members must be experts in hydrographic data and related fields. The panel composition for the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 includes 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, experts in hydrographic data and related fields, along with nonvoting members from the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and NOAA. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amendment to Section 306 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 to authorize appropriations. The Administrator is authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions, excluding hydrographic surveys, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. Additionally, funds are designated for contracting hydrographic surveys, including vessel leasing or time chartering, with specified amounts for fiscal years 2009 to 2011. The Administration is allocated specific amounts for nautical mapping and charting functions, hydrographic survey vessels operation, and geodetic functions for fiscal years 2009 to 2012. For fiscal years 2009 to 2012, specific amounts are allocated for nautical mapping, charting, tide and current measurement functions, and acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel. SEC. 6. Authorized NOAA Corps strength is amended to specify the number of authorized commissioned officers. The authorized number of commissioned officers in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's commissioned corps will increase from 321 to 379 effective October 1, 2009, subject to certain conditions including submission of ship and aircraft plans, availability of funding, and justification of organizational needs.
